Nose Bleeding
Eye injury
Bruising
Bleeding from Ears
//nose bleeding
•To control bleeding.
 •To maintain an open airway.
• Advice the victim to sit upright and lean forward. This helps to reduce blood pressure in the veins of the nose hence discouraging further bleeding.

 •Pinch the victim's nose using the thumb and index finger to shut the nostrils. During this period the patient should breathe through the mouth.

 •Give the victim a tissue or a piece of clean cloth to wipe up any dribbling.

 •Pinch the nose for a period between 5 to 10 minutes.

 •During this period, advice him not to speak, swallow, cough, spit or sneeze because he may disturb blood clots that have formed in the nose.

 •After the period has elapsed, ask the patient to release the pressure and if bleeding has not stopped, reapply the pressure for two further periods of ten minutes each.

 •To avoid re-bleeding, advice the victim not to bend down for several hours or blow their nose after the bleeding episode.

 •During this period, the victim should always keep their head higher than the level of their heart.



//Eye injury
•Urgently transfer the victim to a hospital.
•Help the victim to lie on his or her back and hold his or her head to keep it as still ad possible.

 •Instruct the patient to keep both eyes still since movement of uninfected eye will cause movement of the affected causing further damage and pain.

 •Ask the victim to hold a sterile dressing over the injured eye or you can secure the dressing in place with a bandage.

 •Transfer the victim to a hospital.

 •DO NOT attempt to remove an embedded foreign object in the eye.



//Bruising
•Reduce the flow of blood to the injured area so as to minimize swelling.
•Raise the injured area above the level of the heart if possible. This keeps blood from pooling in the bruised tissue.
 •Apply an ice pack wrapped in a towel for about 5 to 10 minutes. Do not apply the ice directly on the skin.
 •Rest the bruised area and avoid over working muscles around the site of the bruise.
 •Take OCT (over-the-counter) pain relievers such as ibuprofen to relief pain and reduce swelling.


See the doctor when:


•You are still experiencing pain 3 days after a minor injury.
 •You notice painful swelling in the bruised area.
 •You are experiencing abnormal bleeding elsewhere such as nose or gums.
 •Suddenly being bruised and have no history of bruising.
 •Have frequent, large painful bruises especially if they appear on your face or back.
 •Have a family history of easy bruising or bleeding.



//Ear injury
•Urgent transfer the victim to a hospital.

•Gently place a sterile gauze or pad over the ear and NOT inside the victim's ear.

 •Help the victim to lie down on the side with the affected ear facing down so as to allow blood and fluids to drain away.

 •Do not allow the victim to fall asleep, make them calm and relaxed yet awake by asking them questions and reassuring them.

 •Call for an ambulance for urgent medical help.
